(She takes off the plastic cover and looks for the button.) Reset button, reset button, where is there a reset button? (Finds it.) Oh here it is! (Picks it up off of the floor.) Oh! (She presses it hard, but of course it would help if the button was still attached to the detector. In frustration she presses it so hard it causes pain in her thumb.) Ohh, God!
Okay, do-do you have a good grip?
Yeah!
Okay, Im going to start climb down you now.
All right! Just hurry up!
Okay. Now-now-now should I climb down your front so were face to face or-or should I climb down your back so were-were butt to face.
I think face to face.
I would say that.
Face to face, yeah!
Okay, here I go.
All right.
(grunting) Oh my How much do you weigh Ross?!
I prefer not to answer that right now, Im still carrying a little holiday weight.
Yknow, when we talked about face to face, I dont think we thought it all the way through.
So what do you want me to do?
Well, just shimmy down me and drop!
Hi.
Hi.
(looking down) M-maybe I should hang and you can climb down me.
(angrily) Yeah? Maybe we should talk about that for a little while!
Its still looks pretty far!
Its not that far! Just drop!
Do not rush me!!
Ross, you should know that my pants are startin to come down and Im not wearing any underwear!
Oww!! My ankle! I really hurt my ankle! I think I twisted it when IOoh, a quarter!
That really was some of your best work.
Hm-hmm, I told you! (Looks at the clock) I cant believe that Ive only got two hours before I call in sick for work.
I have to be up in seven minutes.
Well, youre not gonna believe this, but if you have seven minutes
Really?!
Do you wanna?
Okay! You get the vacuum cleaner and Ill get the furniture polish!
Brian Buckner & Sebastian Jones Story by: Sherry Bilsing & Ellen Plummer Transcribed by: Eric Aasen
Hey.
Hey.
What are you doing?
Well, yknow I was thinking of moving the couch over here.
(laughs) Why would you want to do that?
So that there will be a decent place for me to sit.
Rach, there is a decent place to
And your lap does not count! Okay? Come on help me move this.
No. No. No.
No?
No. Rosita does not move.
Im sorry, Rosita? As in
As in Rosita does not move.
Joey, its just a chair! Whats the big deal?
The big deal is that it is the exact equal distance from the bathroom to the kitchen and its at the perfect angle so you dont get any glare coming of off Stevie.
Stevie the TV?
(glaring at her) Is there a problem?

No! (Joey sets his beer and bag of chips down and heads into his room.) Oh what does he know! Come on Rosita, us chichas got to stick together! (She tries pulling on the back of the chair, until the hinge breaks and the back falls off.) You bitch!

Hey, yknow whats weird? After you guys get married, when you introduce me to people youre gonna have to say, "This is my brother-in-law Ross." Not, "My friend Ross," "brother-in-law Ross." Thats weird isnt it?
Couldnt I just say, "This is Ross?"
(disappointed) Sure, do whatever you want.
(entering, carrying a newspaper) Hey Ross! So, I was checking out the uh, real estate section
Yeah?
Look at this. (Hands him the newspaper.)
Oh, it looks like mom and dads house. Oh, it even has a tree with a broken limb out front and the uh, the window in the attic isOh my God!!
What? What happened to the window in the attic?!
I cant believe mom and dad are selling the house!
I cant believe they-they didnt even tell us!
I cant believe I still dont know what happened to the window in the attic!
(on phone) Uh, hello dad! Monica and I just saw the house in the paper! (Listens) Yes were surprised! (Listens) Who did you leave a message with?
(knocking on the window while outside) Sorry! (Runs off.)
Joey, Joey I am so sorry.
I told you not to move it! Rach, how would you feel if say, I wanted to move you mom, and you said dont, and I did it anyway and her head fell off?
Okay, come onJoey, Ill buy you a new one! All right? Well go down to the store right now and well-well get you a new chair.
(slowly turning and glaring at her) Shes not even cold yet!
But dont you think Rosita wouldve wanted you to move on? I mean yknow, she did always putyour comfort first.
Thats true.
(grabbing her coat) Okay? You ready?
Yeah, I (Shuts off the TV.) I dont want Stevie to see her like this.
I cant believe we have to say goodbye to the house we grew up in. Man, some-some strangers gonna be living in my room.
Well, after 15 years of mom and dad keeping it as a shrine to you, its time the velvet ropes came down.
They kept your room for a while.
Oh please! Dad turned my room into a gym 20 minutes after I moved out! I gotta say, a tanning bed and a stack of Victorias Secret catalogues, not a gym!
Come on, you know they love you.
As much as they love you?
I was their first born! They thought she was barren! Its not my fault.
(entering) Hey.
Hey.
Hey!
Ugh, I hate this year!
Whats wrong with this year?
Well okay, its already February and Ive only given two massages and they were both the worst tippers in the world!
That was me and Ross.
Oh thats right!
Hey, yknow if you want to pick up some extra cash? Some friends of mine made good money doing telemarketing.
Oh thats a great idea. Youre really good on the phone.
Yeah and yeah, and it would probably be better than the last telephone job I had. Yknow, I probably wouldnt have to say spank as much. (Monica and Ross are shocked.)
What?
Oh yeah, like you never called!
So basically this is very easy. You read from the script and try to sell as much toner as you possibly can.
Okay, I can do that! Oh, by the way, I love my office.
(laughs) Why dont we do a trial run.
Oh okay. Umm, all right. (Picks up the phone and starts reading from the script.) Hi, this is Phoebe from Empire Office Supplies, can I speak to your supply manager please?
Im the supply manager.
Umm, okay I would like to talk to you about your toner needs.
We dont need any toner.
Oh okay, well Im sorry to bother you. Bye-bye. (Hangs up the phone.) Yeah youre right, this is easy.
Okay, what was wrong with that call?
Oh well, all rightum, no offense, but you were kind of rude.
Theyre always going to tell you they dont need toner, but thats okay because whatever they say, you can find the answer to it here in this script.
Oh.
So, I think youre ready to sell toner, do you have any last questions?
No. (Pause) Oh wait yes! I do, I do have one question. What is toner?

Joey! Joe! (Sees that hes not here and starts investigating. He picks up the bag of chips.) Full bag. (He picks up the beer.) Beers still cold. Something terrible mustve happened here! (He decides its not that important; sits down on Rosita, and the back falls off causing him to flip over.) Oh no-no-no-no-no-no! (Runs over to Stevie.) Stevie, I was never here! (Runs out.)
Dad?
Im here!
(entering with Monica) Hey!
Hi. God, it seems like just yesterday you guys used to come out to watch me work.
Dad, we-we cant believe youre selling the house.
Well, its time for a new family to start their memories here and hopefully their check will clear before they find the crack in the foundation and the asbestos in the ceiling.
(To Monica) Lets grab our stuff and get the hell out of here.
Im sorry we cant store your childhood things anymore.
Oh, thats okay, I cant wait to see everything again! All of the memories
Well, I dont know whats in the boxes down here, but I do know there are six or seven Easy Bake Ovens in the attic.
I used to love to play restaurant.
Yeah, not as much as you used to love to play uncooked batter eater.
Hey, it is unreasonable to expect a child to wait for a light bulb to cook brownies! (She goes to the attic.)
So, I think youre boxes are over here. (They walk over to them.)
Wow! Great! (Finds a pack of cigarettes.) Wait, dad who-whos cigarettes are these?
I dont know. They-they must be your mothers, but please, please dont ask her. Ill throw these away. (He puts them in his pocket as Ross finds something of interest in one of his boxes.)
Cool! Dad! My report cards! Hey, check this out dad, (reading his grades) Math, A. Science, A. History, A. Gym(He puts it away and finds something else.) Oooh, my rock polisher!
Oh look, look theres your old makeup kit!
Its a clown kit! Clown kit!
Well, the white seems to be untouched. (He throws it back into the box as Mr. Geller moves a tarp and makes a discovery.) Uh-oh.
What?
Yknow how the garage floods every Spring?
How are you ever going to sell this place?
I think I accidentally used Monicas boxes to keep the water away from the Porsche.
Oh no. Dad! Dad! What(He goes to open one of her boxes and it rips apart.) Oh Godeverythings ruined! Dad, shes gonna be crushed!
You dont secretly smoke do you?
No!
So its just your mother then.

(on phone) Hi, this Phoebe from Empire Office Supplies, can I speak to your supply manager please? (Listens) Earl, thanks. (Listens) Hi Earl, this is Phoebe from Empire Office Supplies Id like to talk to you about your toner needs. (Shes reading from the script.)
I dont need any toner.
Im hearing what youre saying, but at our prices everyone needs toner.
Not me.
May I ask why?
You wanna know why. You wanna know why?
I surely do!
Okay, I dont need any toner because Im going to kill myself.
(doesnt have any luck) Umm, is-is that because youre out of toner?
Okay, sono toner today. Thanks anyway, bye-bye.
No-no wait-wait! I cant just let you hang up! Just please talk to me.
WellI only have one thing to do today. (He looks at his board in his office that reads, "Todays Tasks: KILL SELF.") I guess I could push it back.
Yeah! Now, why do you want to kill yourself?
Its just that I uh, have been working for ten years now at this meaningless, dead-end job and nobody here even knows I exist!
Chandler?
I-Im sorry?
No look, I-Im sure that people know you exist!

Oh yeah? I work in a cubicle surrounded by people. Ive been talking to you for five minutes now about killing myself and no ones even looked up from their desk. Hang-hang on. (To the people standing around his cubicle.) Hey everybody! Uh, Im gonna kill myself! (Theres no response; no one even looks up.) Ill get back to ya. (To Phoebe) I got nothing. Wait. (He sets the phone down.) Uh, hey Marge! (Mimes putting a gun to his head, pulling the trigger, and splattering his brain on the wall behind him. Then points to himself. Marge watches this, then goes back to work.) (To Phoebe) Ehh, nothing. Nothing.

My chair. Now, if anybody asks, your name is Rosita! (He runs out the door, grabs the back of Rosita, and we can hear Joey and Rachel talking as they are coming up the stairs. Neither of them have reached the landing yet.)
You will like it!
No I wont.
You dont even know!
Because, I know what I like and what I dont like! Its not the same thing!
Well look, if you dont like this(The audiences laughter at Chandlers progress cuts out the rest of Rachels line.)
I dont know why you say that so soon.
Come on Joey, I just bought you a new chair! The most expensive one in the store! Hey, yknow what I was thinking? We could name her Francette.
Francette? What is she? A couch?
Poor thing. Cut down in her prime.
Joey, the new chair will be here in an hour. Maybe we should actually move Rosita out of here. Yknow, start the heeling process?

Well, I guess youre right. Maybe, maybe Ill take her down to the incinerator. Its gonna be so said, and kinda cool. (He goes to remove the back, but it doesnt come off. So he sits down in it, puts his feet up, stands up, and looks back at it.) Shes heeled!
Thats weird.
No its not weird, its a miracle!
Its not a miracle Joey! Im sure theres some explanation.
Oh there is! If you want something enough and your heart is pure, wondrous things can happen!
Joey, I really dont
(interrupting her) Can you tell me how this happened?
Well no.
Miracle!
No, yknow what? Maybe somebody came in here and fixed it! Or something!
Someone like anangel?
Thats right Joey, the chair angel came in and heeled your chair. (She sits down in the chair.)
(angrily) Get your non-believer ass outta my chair! (She gets up and heads for her room.)
Well, shell understand right? Its not like I did it on purpose.

Dad that wont matter to her. Look, all my stuff is safe and dry and all her is-is, is growing new stuff! See, this is exactly the kind of thing that makes her think you guys love me more than you love her.
Oh my God, does she really thinks that?
Well, can you blame her?
Well I dont know, I-I suppose we may have favored you unconsciously, you were a medical marvel! The doctor said your mother could
Dad, dad I dont want to hear about it.
Really?

Well, not right now. Okay look, Monica came here for some memories and damnit, were gonna give her some! Okay, grabgrab some empty boxes. Okay? Well-well take stuff from mine and whatever we can pass off as hers well-well put em in their.
Great!
Like uh yknow like this! This! (He picks up one of those art projects that kids make in kindergarten and first grade.) She-she couldve made this!
Sure!
Right? And this! (He picks up a trophy) She-she couldve won this!
(grabbing a glove) This couldve been hers!
Sure! Ooh-ooh, what about this?
Your make-up kit? Id feel better.
(grabbing a beer out of the chairs fridge) I am so psyched I kept this chair for myself!
Yeah, me too. (He flips up his armrest in disgust.)
Hey, howshows the uh, miracle chair?
Fine.
Yeah? Wow! Yknow, that this thing has speakers in the headrest!
No. Really?
Yeah! You can hook it up to your TV and you get radio!
(quietly) My chair heels itself.

Earl, youre not hearing me! All Im saying is that youre not alone all right? Everybody hates the people they work with! (One of her coworkers overhears that, and she mimes that she didnt mean him.)
(walking past Earls desk) Hey guy!
Wait, what was that? That sounded like someone being nice to you.
No! Thats just the "Hey Guy" guy. He says that to everybody! Hes the worst! Id like to take him with me!

All right so Earl, lets just forget about the people at the office, okay? There-theres gotta be someone else in your life worth sticking around for! What about-what about your family, your friends, or maybe your girlfriend?
(laughs) Yeah! Right!
Oh sorry, boyfriend!
Oh no.
No, whatever! Anything!
Hey guy!
Yeah, hes gotta go.
Okay, I should, I should probably be getting back to my thing now. See ya. (Hangs up.)
No! Im not finished yet! Dont! Dont you dare hang up on me!!!
(walking by and overhearing that) (to the rest of the staff) The new girls good.
Hey guys! Hey!
Hey.
Hey, I just whipped us up some Easy Bake treats, they should be ready in about three days.
(overacting) Thats a good one! Do you hear that Ross? Three days!
(overacting as well) Yeah! Yeah! (Laughs.) Oh, this will make a great memory.
(wary) Okay. So, which boxes are mine?
Well, these. These are yours right here. (Pointing to the boxes they just created for her.)
Okay. (Starting to go through them) Oh! A coloring book! (Holding it up.)
Yeah. Yeah, oh you loved that thing. You always had it with you. You never went anywhere without-without that coloring book.
(looking through it) Really? Wow! It looks like I had some trouble staying inside the lines.
Nu-uh! (Grabs it and examines it.)
(holding up a glove) Oh, an old glove?
Oh, yeah you loved that glove! You took it every place you went. You never went any place without that glove.

Wow! Look at this! (Picking up a shirt.) I cant believe I even fit into this shirt! (She holds it up and it reads: Tyrannosaurus Ross.) (She turns it around and looks at it.) Oh, this is yours. (Hands it to Ross.)
Oh, I dont know how that got in there.

(holding up a small cowboy hat) This isnt mine. (Sets it down and looks at the rest of the boxes.) Hey, this isnt, this isnt my stuff! Ugh, Ross! (Grabs and holds up a doll.) These are your boxes! Where are my boxes?
Umm, your boxes are umm
What?
Dad?
Well, the garage flooded sweetie and it ruined everything in your boxes. Im sorry.
Just mine?
Im afraid so.
So why-why wasnt Rosss stuff ruined? (Pause) And if you say the words medical marvel Im going to Easy Bake your head!
Well, I used your boxes to divert water away from the Porsche.
So wait, Rosss stuff is fine, but I have no memories because you wanted to keep the bottom two inches of your car away from water!!!
There was also leaves and guk and stuff.
I cant believe this! (Storms out.)
(To Ross) Screw it! Im having one. (Takes out and lights a cigarette.)
Hey Chandler!
Hey!
How would you like to sit in a chair that fully reclines, has a rolling massage, and speakers in the head rest?
Yeah, Id love to but Ive tried that so many times they wont even let me in the store anymore.
Well what if I told you, you can do it in my apartment?
(excitedly) Are you telling me that you bought the chair that is making all other lounge systems obsolete? The chair that Sit magazine called the Chair of the Year?
I just purchased the La-Z-Boy E-cliner 3000. (Which is an actual product by the way, Im not sure about the 3000 part.)
Thats awesome! Thats great! What made you do it?!
Well, its a long story, but umm I broke Joeys chair
Whoa-whoa-whoa! You broke Joeys chair?
Yeah.
I thought I broke Joeys chair! Thats why I replaced it with mine!
Ohhhhh. Thats how it got fixed!
Well, what did you think, that-that elves came in and fixed it?
Noo! (Laughs) Angels.
Im gettin my chair back! (Heads for Joey and Rachels.)
What? Wh-hey!
Well, it looks like it wasnt heeled after all! Yeah! So, I guess this chair is mine now! (Sits down in it and groans.)
Joey you broke my chair!!
Your chair?!
Yeah, he thought he broke your chair so he switched the chairs!
So, there was no miracle?!
No Joe, no miracle.
(sarcastic) Oh no this is devastating! My faith is shaken. Im so glad I have the new chair to get my through this difficult time in my life.
Uh-huh! Nice try, but you dont get that chair anymore! All right? That is my chair now! You can sit on my lap! (Joey starts to get up.) No I take that back!
I think I should get the chair!
How do you figure?
Because you (Points to Joey) broke a chair and you (Points to Rachel) broke a chair! The only one around here that hasnt broke a chair, is me!
No-no-no! This chairs not going anywhere.
Well, wheres the logic in that?!
The logic is, that there are two of us and we are both strong enough to break a chair in half!
So Joey breaks my chair and I get nothing!
Thats right!
What are you guys? Like a gang or something?!
Yeah! We are!
Were the Cobras!
(to Marge) Excuse me! Can you tell me where I can find Earl? Hes the supply manager around here.
Sorry, I dont know any Earl.
(screaming) Im right here!!!!
(goes over to his desk) Earl! Im Phoebe.
Phoebe? The lady who sells toner?
Umm, look it, you-you cant kill yourself.
(exhales) Look, um I really appreciate your coming down
No-no I cant! I cant let you do it!
Why?!
Because it was fate that made me call you today!
I thought it was toner.

No! Think about it okay? This isnt even my regular job! Okay? And my first day on the job, youre my first call! And-and somebody else mightve hung up on you, but I wouldnt do that because I know about this stuff. My mom killed herself.
Really?!
Yes.
How?
Im not gonna give you tips! Look dont you see that this-thisthis all came together so that I could stop you from doing this.
Couldnt it just be a coincidence?
No, its fate!
It doesnt really seem like enough to be fate.
Oh. Well umm, okay heres a weird thing. My mother was also a supply manager.
Im actually the office manager.
Oh my God! So was she! And! Get this, okay? Your-your name is Earl, right? Her name was Pearl, P-Earl.
Well, was there anything else?!
Sure! (Thinks.) Umm, where are you from?
Philadelphia.
Oh my God! So was she! Oh, Ive got-Ive got goose bumps. (She holds out her arm.)
(inspecting it) Really?
Well, yknow Im wearing layers and its warm.
Yeah-yeah.
But ifno look, okay. These jerks might not care about you, but the universe does! And that says a lot!

(To All) Did you hear that?! I dont need you guys to care about me! Because the universe cares! The whole universe! (Laughs as everyone ignores him.) (To Phoebe) I really wished theyd care just a little bit though.
Yknow, I dont-I dont think its you. This is a freaky place. (To All) Hey! Guys! (Everyone looks up.) (To Earl) Oh no, its you.
Yeah.

Oh, this terrible! Everything is destroyed! Look at this. (She picks up some kind of furry thing.) It obviously meant enough for me to save it, and I dont even know what it is! Ohh, its still soft. (She rubs it against her cheek.) What do you think this is?
All right. I think it was a mouse.
(entering) How are you honey?
How do you think I am?! Youve wrecked all my childhood memories. You love Ross more than me. And I just rubbed a dead mouse on my face!
Sweetheart, we love you just as much as Ross! Now, Im sorry about everything that happened and Id probably never be able to make it up to you, but heres a start. (He hands her a small box.)
(opening it) Whats this?
Its the key to my Porsche. Well, the key to your Porsche.
(shocked) What?!
(even more shocked) What?!!!
Ive been thinking about getting rid of it. I was driving it the other day and saw my reflection in a store window. Your mothers right, I do look like an ass.
Wait, youre giving me your Porsche, youre kidding me right?!
Well w-w-w-w-wait, w-wait, wait, wait a minute! I mean a couple of stupid boxes get wet and she gets a Porsche?!
(To Monica) Why dont we take it for a spin?
All right!
Well, what about me?! Im a medical marvel!!
Oh yeah.
Ahhhh.
Ahhh (To Rachel) Eh?
Uh-huh.
(entering) Hey guys!
Hey!
Hey!
Do you guys know what happened to Chandlers barca lounger?
Oh yeah, Joey broke it. Had to get rid of it.
Are you kidding?! I get a Porsche and the barca loungers gone?! This is the best day ever! (Runs out.)
Sherry Bilsing & Ellen Plummer Story by: Vanessa McCarthy Transcribed by: Eric Aasen
Happy birthday!!!
Happy birthday!!!
Rach! Come on! Rach!
Its your birthday!
(entering from her room) Hey.
(To Monica) Shes not as pretty as she was when she was 29.

Ms. Green would like to establish some ground rules before she comes out. She would appreciate it if you dont use the words old or downhill or (To Joey) they still look pretty damn good. (Joey smiles and everyone glares at him.)
They do!
Rachel! Come on out! Monica made breakfast!
Chocolate-chip pancakes!
Weve got presents!
Good ones?
They all came from the list you handed out to us two weeks ago.
Well, can I keep the presents and still be 29?
Come on Rach! Look, turning thirty is not that big a deal.
Oh really. Is that how you felt when you turned thirty?
(screaming) Why God?!! Why?!! We had a deal!! Let the others grow old! Not me!! (He buries his head in Phoebes lap for comfort.)
Yknow, Im still 29 in Guam.
Hey, 30 is not that old! Do you know how old the Earth is?
Late thirties? Oh come on you guys! Is it just me? Am I overreacting to this?
No Rach, its not just you. My thirtieth birthday certainly wasnt that much fun.
(screaming) And now Chandler! Were all gettin so old! (Looking up) Why are you doing this to us?! (Turns away crying.)
Rach, youre in a great place in your life. Come on, youve got a great job! Good friends
Yeah, youre roommate is a soap opera star.
Look, yknow I know my lifes going pretty well, but I look around and I just see so many people whove accomplished so many other goals by the time theyre thirty.
Yeah, but you shouldnt compare yourself to me.
Come on Phoebe! You can do it Phoebe! Come on!
There you go!

I did it! One mile on a hippity-hop! Thats it!! Thats everything I wanted to do before I was thirty. Oh, except I wanted to patch things up with my sister. But oh well. Yay!! (They all cheer again.) And-and girls this thing is a Godsend if you know what I mean. (Rachel and Monica look intrigued and as they all head into Central Perk, Rachel picks up the hippity-hop that Phoebe left behind.)
Thirty. Ugh, I mean thirty! Monica, do you remember mean, old Mrs. Kreeger in the fifth grade? She was thirty!
Come on, lets have some fun. Huh? (To Rachel) What do you want to do today?
Nothing. I dont want to do anything.
Well, doing nothing on your thirtieth is better than doing something stupid, like Ross.
Hey! That was a practical purchase! I needed that car for transportation! Okay? I-I have a child!
How hot do I look in this, huh?!
Ross, a sports car? Wouldnt it have been cheaper to just stuff a sock down there?
Thats not what this is about okay? I-I am a sports car enthusiast. I have always been into cars.
Hey, whats the horsepower on this thing?
(giddy) I dont know, but-but look how shiny!
I cant believe you bought this.
Really! God Ross, what were you thinking? (To Phoebe, quietly) I know its really shallow, but a part of me wants him again.
Oh, well get in line missy. (To Ross) So, can I have a ride stud?
Hop in. (Phoebe hops in.) Get ready for the smoothest ride of your life.
Damnit! (Shuts the car off.)
(getting out) Okay, whos next?
Yknow what? I am going to do something today. Im not just gonna sit around like some old lady. Im gonna get something pierced. Like my uh, like my nose or my tongue or something.
Really?! Cause yknow that hurts.
So what?! Yknow what? The way I see it(Phoebe pulls out a hair from the back of her head)Ow! Son of a bitch!!
Look Rachel, I know what youre going through. Im totally freaked about turning 25.
(glares at him) Get out, get out of my apartment.
All right Rach, for what its worth, I think that youre doing great. I mean yknow lets face it, no one handles this well.
Least of all you.
Why? What youd do?
Werent you asked to leave sonny?
(To Joey) Would you put that back on?! Monicas gonna be here any minute!
But it hurts my Joeys Apple.
(frustrated) Okay, for the last time. Its not named for each individual man.
(To Chandler) Youve done a wonderful job with this party Chandler. Everything looks so lovely.

Oh well, not as lovely as you. I mean, I cant believe that you would have a thirty-year-old daughter! (To Mr. Geller) And you! I cant believe that you would have a tux thats thirty years old! (Puts his hand on Mr. Gellers shoulder.)
Its older than that. Ross was actually conceived right near this tuxedo.
Ohh! (He quickly removes his hand and looks at it.)
(entering) Hey! Everybody hide! Hide! I saw her! Shes coming!
Okay! Okay! Everybody down! Everybody down! (Rachel turns off the lights and everyone crouches. As everyone crouches, a ripping noise erupts from the assemblage.)
Crap.
(getting up to investigate) Okay, everybody stay here. I will find out whats going on.
Heyyy!! You got the door open!! (Giggles.)
Hey-hey are you drunk?

Nooo! (Giggles) Okay. (She tries to pull herself up by Rachel and Joeys doorknob, but the door opens and she almost falls into the their apartment. She manages to catch herself.) Whoa! (Stands up, unsteadily) Okay. See I was, I was a little nervous about turning (whispering) thirty. (Giggles.) So the bus boys took me out for some drinks. (Pause) I wanna puke on you later!
Okay, here is the thing. We have thrown a very formal surprise party for you in there! All of your friends are in there and your parents!
Noo!!!
Yes!
Noo!!
Yes!!
Oh no! My parents have never seen me drunk! (Pause) That they know of.
Okay, heres the thing. Were gonna get you some coffee and they will never know that youre drunk.
Really?! You promise?
Yeah, Ill take care of it.
Okay. I love you so much. (Kisses him.)
(laughing) Okay we have to do something about your breath.
What about your breath?! (Breathes on him.)
Thats still yours. Okay, now remember its a surprise party. So, when you go in, act surprised.
Okay. I can do that.
Okay.
Surprise!!!
Okay, forward. ForwardStop! (The car moves an inch and Ross runs to the back of the car.) Okay, backStop! (The car barely moves and Ross runs back to the front.) Okay, forwardStop! Stop! Stop!
Ross, just forget about it. This guys got you totally wedged in.
(To Joey) Is this yours?
Well actually
No-no-no! Its mine! Its-its mine. (The woman walks away.)
Dude, you soooo need this car.

(running up) Okay. Okay, heres what were gonna do. Okay, Im gonna break into this mini-van and put it in neutral. You guys push it forward so Ross can drive out of his spot. Okay? All right, here we go. (She opens her coat and reveals that thing car thieves use to break into cars as Ross jumps in behind the wheel. She inserts the device, unlocks the door, opens it, and the alarm goes off.) Haul ass!!!! (Runs off.)
Happy thirtieth birthday! Here! (Hands her the hippity-hop.) Its for the child in you, and the woman. Happy thirtieth!
Right, why do you keep saying that?
Because its our thirtieth birthday.
Yeah, no were not thirty. Were 31. Okay. (She closes the door.)
Wait! (Knocks on the door and Ursula opens it.)
Oh, its you.
Yeah. What?!
Yeah, were not thirty, were 31.
Nu-uh!
Yea-huh! Thats what is says on my birth certificate.
You have your birth certificate?
Yeah, I got a big box of family stuff when my mom died.
Our mom.
(sarcastic) Right! Okay. (Hands Phoebe her births certificate.)
Do you have my birth certificate?
No, I sold it to a Swedish runaway.
(reading the certificate) Oh my God! Oh my God, we are 31.
Yeah.
I just lost a whole year of my life.
(sarcastic) Okay.
Your middle name is Pamela?
Yes.
Well, I never knew mine. Do you remember what it is?
Yes! Phoebe.
Thats my first name.
Right, okay, then no.
Okay before we start the celebration, Monica has to go put on her party dress.
Yay!
See? (Does his laugh.) Here we go. (Starts walking her to their room, and has to pass in front of Mr. Geller whos sitting at the table and Mrs. Geller whos standing next to him.)
Happy birthday, sweetie! Give us a hug! (Starts to get up.)
(stopping him) Dont get up Jack! The safety pins are about to blow.
(sees someone) Paul!
(correcting her) Phil.
Phil!
Now, there is a dress laid out on your bed. (Monica stumbles on the steps.) Okay, (catches her) youre doing great. Youre doing great. Youre doing fine.
Hey, whats going on?
Monicas a little drunk.
Yay! I love drunk Monica!
Awwwww (Giggles.)
(To Monica) Go change! (To Phoebe) She doesnt want her parents to know shes drunk.
Ohh! All right! All right. Heres what well do, Ill get twice as drunk as Monica and then no ones will even notice her.
Whats-whats going on? Phils really pissed!
Monicas wasted.
Maybe that will liven up this party.
(To Rachel) Okay, will you just go help her change please!
Okay, but taking care of a drunk, naked woman seems like a job for Joey.
Yep. (Starts for Monicas room, but Chandler stops him.)
(handing his to her) This ones from me.
Ahh!
It wasnt on your list, but hopefully youll think its really fun.
(opening it) A scooter! (Shes not happy.)
(to Tag) Stick to the list. Always stick to the list.
No! No-no, I love it. Thank you. (Kisses him.)
Okay, open ours next. Open ours next!
Okay.
Now that youre a couple, we dont get two presents from you guys?
For my last birthday you gave me a hug! (To Rachel) Okay, read the card! Read the card!

Okay. (Opens the card and reads it.) Happy birthday Grandma! Its better to be over the hill (starting to cry) then buried under it. (Breaks down as everyone glares at them.) All our love Monica and Chandler. (Crying) Thats funny, yeah!
No-no-no-no! That was the joke!
(crying) No, I know! I get it! Its funny!
No, because youre not a grandmother!
No I know, because to be a grandmother you have to be married and have children and I dont have any of those things. Thats why its so funny. (Runs into her room crying.)
All you had to do was buy the card!
Hey! Look whos back! Its the birthday girl! Hows the birthday girl feeling?
Well, I feel fine, but I think youre bumming out the rest of the kids.
What? (Glances over and sees the faces of the rest of the group, then goes and sits down.)
Okay! Yknow what? I realized it was stupid to get upset about not having a husband and kids. All I really needed was a plan. See I wanna have three kids
Oh let me guess, and you wanna have them all at the same time and you wanna have them for your brother.
As I was saying I should probably have the first of the three kids by the time Im 35 which gives me five years. I love this plan! I wanna marry this plan!
If you could do that, Id marry the hippity-hop.

So, if I wanna have my kid when Im 35, I dont have to get pregnant until Im 34. Which gives Prada four years to start making maternity clothes! Oh wait, but I do want to be married for a year before I get pregnant
Really! That long?! (Chandler slowly turns and looks at her.) (To Chandler) Look all you want, its happening!

No, so I dont have to get married until Im 33! Thats three years, thats three whole yearsOh, wait a minute though. Ill need a year and a half to plan the wedding, and Id like to know the guy for a year, year and a half before we get engaged Which means I need to meet the guy by the time Im thirty.
Which is fine! Because you just turned(Removes two candles from the cake)twenty-eight!
No! Ross, no! It is not fine! Eh-eh-according to my plan I should already be with the guy I wanna marry!
Will you quit hoggin it!
(To Chandler) Im telling you its like watching Bambi learn how to walk.
(To Monica) Youre drunk! Mom and dad are gonna be maaaaadd! Maybe Im a little drunk.
(to a waiter) Oh thats great! Right there! Can we get some of that over here please? (The waiter comes over) There we go.
(to the waiter) Hey! Are those crab cakes? (The waiter nods) Did I not tell ya to come straight to me when more crab cakes were ready?
(To Monica) How are you feeling?
You are so handsome! I wanna make love to you right here, right now! (Growls and pulls him into a kiss.)
I really wish that you wouldnt.
(To Monica) Now all you have to do is just get through a little bit more, okay? Then we can put you in bed, okay? Just smile and dont talk to anyone.
(clinking two glasses together) Speech! Speech! Lets hear from the birthday girl! Huh?
Pheebs!!
Dont you see? Everyones looking at me! The plans working! I didnt even have to take off my top yet!
Speech! Come on Monica!
Come on!
Come on! Speech!
(filming this) Hey Chandler, you cant keep your hands off her for one second!
Oh-ho, I think its nice.
I think its necessary. (Backs away anyhow.)
I-I-I wanna thank you all for coming. My family and my friends
(screaming) Wooo!! Hoo!!

I really like to say that Im-um (Pause) Yknow what Id really like to say? Im drunk!! (Mrs. Geller pulls the camera down.) Thats right mom and dad your little Harmonica is hammered!! (Ross grabs the camera out of his dads hands.) And guess what! Ive been drunk before! And Ive smoked a cigarette! And I got a box of Ding-Dongs hidden in my underwear drawer! Its all okay. Its okay because I turned thirty today. And, and I can do anything I want! Because I am a grown up. (Falls over sideways with Ross filming the fall.)
(To Joey) Okay quick, help me get this off! (Motions to her top.)
Yeah!!
I lost a whole year! I cant believe it! This is so unfair!
Oh, I dont know Pheebs. Itll be okay.
Will it? Will it?! I mean, how would you feel if you found out you were 31?
Thats not gonna happen. No. (Looks up) Because we have a new deal!
Plus, it totally ruined my schedule! II havent done any of the things I wanted to do by the time I was 31!
Like what?
Like okay I-I-I, I havent met any Portuguese people! I, I havent had the perfect kiss! And I havent been to snipers school!
Phoebe, yknow why dont we just go upstairs and have some birthday cake?
No, I just feel like being by myself for a while. All right? Ill see you guys later. Thanks. (Gets up and exits.)
Hey. (After she leaves.) Oh, poor Pheebs.
Hey, yknow what you guys? I think Im gonna go walk her home. (Gets up and runs out.)
Oh man!
What?
Hes gonna eat the cake!
Pheebs! Wait up! (She stops.) Listen uh, close your eyes. (She does so and Joey passionately kisses her.) Maybe thats one thing you can cross off your list.
Oh yeah.
Oh, and plus Im 1/16th Portuguese.
Oh! (Phoebe walks away smiling.)
Okay, is everybody clear? Were gonna pick it upand move it. Now all we need is teamwork, okay? Were gonna lift the carand slide it out. Lift and slide!
Ross, I really dont think
(interrupting her) Lift!! And slide!
Okay, here we go.
All right everyone, lift! (They and try to lift the car, of course it doesnt raise up) And slide!! (Everyone leans over, but the car still does not move.)
Hey Joey, can I
Oh, come on Rach! My turn just started!
Actually, I just wanna talk to Tag.
Oh. Okay. Hey, can I ride this outside?
Whatever! Okay, Im not your mother.
Okay! (Runs off downstairs.)
Not in the street!!
Yes!
(to Tag) Hi.
Hey.
Hey.
How are you doing? Are you feeling any better?
Yeah, Im doing okay. Im umlets talk.
Okay. (They sit on the step.)
Umm
Whats up?
Ohh Tag, ummyoure such a great guy and we have sooo much fun together but I dont-I dont
Wait! I think I see where youre going, but before you say anything else, can I just say one more thing? (Kisses her.)
Well said. And a uh good example of the fun I was referring to uhh, but I just think Im past the point where I think I can yknow, just have fun.
Rachel, dont do this. This is just because youre turning thirty.
Yeah, it is! But youre just a kid! I mean youre 25!
Twenty-four actually.
Oh God! Yknow what I wish? I wish you were six years older. Well actually, if Im wishin for stuff, I actually wish I was six years younger.
Me too.
Yeah, Im sorry. (They hug.)
Hey! Howd it go?
Oh, if I only want two kids, can I keep him for another year?
You did the right thing.
(entering, limping, and holding his arm) I dont like this anymore. (He sits down with them in pain.)
Well, here we are, just a bunch of thirty year olds.
God, do you realize in ten years were gonna be 40?
(crying) Why God?! Why are you doing this to us?! (He buries his head in Rosss shoulder.)
Yes! My babys finally free!
All-all right! (They run and jump in the car.) Start it up! Lets go!
(starting it) Woohoo!
How hot are we? (He drives off.)
You wanna buy a car?
No.
There was no credits scene with this episode.}
Andrew Reich & Ted Cohen Story by: Sherry Bilsing & Ellen Plummer Transcribed by: Eric Aasen
Im glad youre here, we have a couple of things to ask you about the wedding ceremony.
(starting to cry) Ohh
Whats the matter? You okay?
Yeah, its just yknow
(To Ross) Monica said wedding.
Uh, so anyway, we thought one of you could read something during the ceremony.
Oh! I would love to read a poem.
Do you think you could get through a poem?
(crying) Itll be a short one.
Okay, so Ross will be doing the reading.
Ohhh
Okay. Yeah, I guess, I guess I could do that too.
Too?
Yeah, I kind of uh, have something else planned for you guys.
Do you mind telling us what it is?
Sorry, Im kinda keeping this one on the Q.T.
Well, whatever it is, I hope it involves winking. (Winks in a spy-type manner.)
(entering, excited) Hey!
Hey!
So I just talked to one of the DOOL writers today, and
What is DOOL?
Days Of Our Lives. Anyway, youre not gonna believe it! My character is coming out of his coma!!
Oh!!
Thats great!
And-and-and not only that, Im gettin a new brain!!
So great things are happening at work and in your personal life!
Wait, what do you mean youre getting a new brain?
Oh well, theyre killing off one of the characters on the show, and when she dies her brain is being transplanted into my body.
What? A brain transplant?!
(seriously) Yes, its a highly controversial procedure.
Its ridiculous!
Well, I think its ridiculous that you havent had sex in three and a half months.
(to Monica and Rachel) Its winter, they are fewer people on the street. (Rachel and Monica smile and nod, knowingly.)
Who are they killing off?
Uh Cecilia Monroe, she plays Jessica Lockhart.
Shes my favorite character on DOOL.
Nice.
She is so good at throwing drinks in peoples faces, I mean I dont think Ive ever seen her finish a beverage.
And the way she slaps all the time!
Oh!
Wouldnt you love to do it just once?! (Raises her hand towards Chandler.)
Dont do it.
Cecilia Monroe man, what a great actress.
Oh, tell me about it. And shes been on the show forever, its gonna be really hard to fill her shoes.
Yeah-yeah, help me out here, when you come out of the "brain transplant," you are going to be her?
Yes, but in Drake Remorays body. (Ross laughs unbelievably.) Why is this so hard for you to get? I thought you were a scientist!
(Clears Throat) Rach, so, that guy there. Straight or gay?
(They both look behind them.) Well, I'd have to say gay.
Yeah? Why?
Well mainly because he's kissing that other guy.
Oh no not that guy there. That guy right there. (Pointing to an attractive man sitting at a table behind them.)
Oh yeah he's too cute to be straight.
(A woman with large breasts walks in the door) Ohh knockers will help us figure it out. (She walks by and he checks her out.)
All right, straight, and not subtle. (The man gets up and leaves.)
Ohh, he left his cell phone.
Oh, well, we can hand it to Gunther and he'll put it in lost and found.
Or we could use it to call China. See how those guys are doing.

What if, um, if he calls his own cell phone to find out who found it and I answer and we start talking and we fell in love. I mean wouldn't that be a great story? Kind of like a fairy tale for the digital age.
Yeah That does sound great. I'm going to get the phone. (They both get up.)
What? Wait! Whywhy do you get the story?
I don't know. I haven't been out on a date in so long.
Phoebe, you had a date three days ago.
That wasnt a date! That was, that was just friends getting together(quietly) having sex.
Okay. Okay, see? I get the phone.
No way! No way! You just broke with Tag a week ago.
Yeah! (Breaking up) And until now, I didnt think Id love again.
Nice try.
Oh hey-hey wait! How do we fairly decide who gets the phone?
I dont know.
Well umm, maybe we could uhh (Grabs the phone) Ah-ha! Too slow!!
Ah-ha! Too cocky!
Im going to keep dating him Mother, and theres nothing you can do about it!
Oh yes there is!
What are you going to do? Kill him? Like you did with Charles?!
(gasps) That was an accident! And so were you.
Well, at least Im not a murderer! (Jessica slaps her.)
(crying) Oh, my baby! (Hugs Dina, but moves Dinas head to her other shoulder so that shes the only one in the picture.)
Cut!
That was a great scene! And-and-and that slap looks so real! How do you do that?
Oh, just years of experience.
(crying) Can I get some ice here?!
Oh anyway, I just wanted to say how wonderful I think you are.
Youre not the fan whos dying are you?
Say what?
Im supposed to meet and hug a fan whose dying, but thats not supposed to be until (to no one in particular) later!
No. No, Im Joey Tribbiani; we did a scene together yesterday. I-Im the guy in the coma!
Oh that was a real person?!
An-an-anyway I-I just wanted to say that since Im getting your brain when you leave the show, I was wondering if there was any tips you can give me
I-I-Im leaving the show?
(quickly) I dont know. Why? Did you hear something?
Who told you that?
Oh uh, one of the writers.
Which one? Was it bald or was it tall?
Umm
Yknow what? It doesnt matter! Because it is not true!
Okay.
And if it were true, how dare you come to me ask me for tips about a character that Ive been playing for 20 yearsIll give you a tip! (She throws her drink in his face.)
Ms. Monroe (She slaps him) Oh there you go. (She storms off, leaving Joey standing next to Dina. They share a nod at the ferocity of the slap they just received.)

No Phoebe! You cannot get the phone that way; thats not fair! Okay look, I have an idea. Why dont we, why dont we see what kind of number he has on his speed dial, and then from that we can tell who has more in common with him. And then whoever does gets the phone.
Or, we can decide by whose ever name is closer to the word phone.
I dont think so.
(handing Rachel the phone) Fine all right, but Id bet youd be singing another tune if we were fighting over a ratchet.
(checking the speed dial) All right, first name on the speed dial is mom.
Ohh, I lost my mom to suicide.
Okay no way, you cannot use that to get the cute guy and the last blueberry muffin.
Did I use that already today? Im sorry.
Yes okay. (Checking the speed dial again.) Well now see this isnt telling us anything. (Reading the speed dial) Joe. Carlos. Peter. Ooh! Peter Luger! T hats a steak house!
Okay, a meat eater. Fine, thats one for you.
(looking at the speed dial) Oh, I win! Hes got Barneys on his speed dial.
So you dont know thats Barneys the store! That can be yknow his friends house, or a bar. Who has Barneys the store on their speed dial?
(showing Phoebe her phone) His new girlfriend!
What is that?
I think its the dying cat parade.
It sounds like its coming from across the street.
(turning around and looking) Oh my God!
What?
Yknow that thing that Ross was gonna do at our wedding?! He was hanging out with me yesterday and he turned to me and said, "Youre half Scottish right?"
Nooo!!
Yes!!
No, there is no way! It can not be Ross! (She looks through the window and sees Ross practicing and fumbling around with the pipes.) Unbelievable! Why is your family Scottish?!
Why is your family Ross?!
He cannot play at our wedding! I mean everyone will leave! I mean come on, that is just noise! Its not even a song!
If you listen very carefully, I think its Celebration by Cool and the Gang.
Hi Pheebs!
Hi!
How are ya?
Good.
Umm Pheebs, remember when we were in the coffee house we decided that I was going to keep the uh, the cute guys cell phone?
Yeah.
And remember how I said I was going to keep it in my purse so that if it rang I could just pick it up?
Yeah!
And do you remember going into my purse and stealing the phone?!
Ooh, now you lost me.
You stole the phone!
No I didnt!
No? So youre saying that if I called it, it wouldnt ring?
No.

Umm, okay. But while you dial, let me show you the features of my new ringing handbag. (Rachel dials her phone and Phoebes bag starts to ring.) Oh, it does work! (Rachel grabs the phone and takes it out of Phoebes handbag.)
Phoebe!
That is a different phone.

Oh is it?! (She answers the cute guys phone.) Uhh, hello? (On her phone) Yes hi, is Rachel there? (On the other phone) Yes she is, just one moment please. (To Phoebe, holding out both phones.) Its for me!
That is damning evidence.

Oh my God! I bet thats him. My digital fairy tale is about to begin. I wonder how I should be? Should I be uh (In a sexy voice) Hello? Or should I be (Happily) Hi! Its Rach (Phoebe knocks the phone out of Rachels hand, catches it, and answers it.) Would you stop doing that?!
(on phone) Hello? (Listens) Yes, Im the one who found your phone.
Phoebe! You cant do th

(To Rachel) Shhh! Im on a call! (On phone) Umm well yeah, you can pick it up tonight, say 8:30? At-at my apartment. Its umm, its umm 5 Morton Street, Apartment 14, umm and then maybe yknow after we can grab a bite to eat or whatever. (Listens) Okay, well okay Ill see you then. (Listens) Bye. (Hangs up.)
You do know that I will be here when he comes over.
Oh? And how will you know what time to come over?
You just said it!
Oh. Okay, well I-I was kinda hoping that I would justbe alone yknow to think about my mom and her suicide.
Oh Phoebe!
What?! Thats the first time today!
Ohh! (Exits.)
So you like the nachos uh? Myself Im partial to
(interrupting) Im 16.
See you in 2003. (She walks away.)
(walking up) Youre absolutely right they are writing me out of the show. They dont know exactly when its going to happen, but apparently going to be very soon and thats it.
Im so sorry. Look, if it was up to me you would never leave the show.
Yeah, thanks.
No I mean it! I cant believe they would do this to you! And to your fans! I mean they are going to be devastated! Heart broken! They love you so much!
Oh youre right. Thank you! Whats your name again?
Joey.
Joey, well thank you. That is so sweet. Oh, excuse me. (She throws her drink on a passing writer.)
It wasnt my decision!
(to him) Im having a conversation here! (To Joey) You were saying?

Uh yeah-ye-ye-ye-ye-yel-l-l-l-l-look the-the-the only reason that I, that I came up to you before was because well, Im really nervous about-about being you. Yknow if you can help me capture the essence of the character. Yknow? Help me keep Jessica alive. Please?
All right Joey, I will help you. Not because I-I owe it to this stupid show, but because I owe it to Jessica.
Oh thats great! Oh thank you so much!
Youre so welcome.
Hey! Now, Ive been watching some tapes, hows this? (In a British accent.) "Jessica Lockhart will never step foot in this place again! Ever!!"
Is that supposed to be me?
Yeah.
Yeah but Jessica doesnt have an English accent.
(shocked) I can do an English accent?! That babys going on my resume!
Well, I feel like a snack!
Do you want some shortbread? Eh thats Scottish like you are.
Oh no thanks. I dont like any thing from my Scottish heritage.
What?!
Well its just my entire family was run out of Scotland byVikings. Anyway, lots of bad memories. (Makes a few unintelligible noises.)
Oh well, it sounds to me like your family is ready to uh, rediscover its Scottish roots.
No! No-no theyre not. Theyre still very angry! But yknow Chandler is also half-Swedish. You know what the Swedish people are famous for? Sitting down and being quiet.
Well yeah-yeah the Scottish history is so much more
(interrupting) You can not play bagpipes at the wedding!!
How did you know about that?!
We heard you play all the way from your apartment!
Were you the ones called the cops?!
Thats not really important right now. What is important is; while we appreciate the gesture, we just dont feel bagpipes are appropriate for our wedding.
Why not?
Because we hate them.
Come on thats not fair! I mean you havent even heard me play!
We have heard you play.

No, youve heard my practice. Okay? Just-just give me a chance to perform for you and then decide whatever you want. And Im not going to tell you what song Im gonna play either. But uh, lets just say when its over Ill bet there will be a we bit o celebration.
So, the essence of the character is rooted in her confidence. So, when Jessica enters a room for instance, she owns everything and every person in that room. (Joey is nodding.) You try.
Okay! (He scurries out the set door and re-enters, extremely impressed) All right!
No, he already knows that he owns everything in the room! Hes not finding it out for the first time! So, try it again.
Okay. Okay. (He goes out and comes back in, glaring at everything.)

Right. Hes not angry at the room either. Try it again, he owns it! He owns the room. It is his. He owns, owns, owns, owns the room! He owns it!! (Joey gets a snooty look on his face.) All right, its a little weird, but its getting better. (Joey is pleased.) Oh well, Im gonna miss this woman so much. I dont know what Im going to do! I mean, its been 20 years of my life.
Oh wellHey-hey! Maybe, maybe uh, maybe this is a good thing. Yknow? Itll-itll give you a chance to shake things up, play different characters. Youre so talented.
I am. I am, but I dont know you know. An actor of a certain age is not that easy.
Hey thats not true! Look at uh, look at Angela LansbAngelina Jolie!
I probably shouldve just left years ago when the offers were pouring in, but yknow I just got so comfy here! And Ohh, I turned down some amazing work!
Like-like what?
Well, lets just say if I left 15 years ago, the landscape of Mexican cinema would be very different today!
(impressed) Wow!
But Well now, nows a different time for me. (Starts to cry.)

Oh hey come on, dont-dont-dont do this! Umm, look let-let me tell you something, okay? Now when I watch you do a scene, Im thinking, "Boy, she-she is a great actress!" (Shes not buying it.) Uh but-but, I am also thinking, "She is hot!"
(intrigued) You think Im hot?
You own the room. (She smiles and stares longingly into his eyes.) We should probably get-get uh
Oh yeah-yeah, we should get the (Pause) So when Jessica kisses a man, she usually puts umm, both her hands on the mans face. (She does so.)
Yeah-yeah, I noticed that! Is that cause shes so passionate?
No! Its because that way the camera only sees her! (She takes her hands off his face.) Do you wanna try it?
Yeah! Okay. (He puts his hands on her face and they kiss.)

That was good, that was really good. But I-I think your hands maybe a little off, they should be maybe right like (She grabs the back of his neck and kisses him passionately causing them to fall onto the couch.)
Hey! Hey!
Whoa! Why do you get to answer the door?
Well why shouldnt I?!
Because its my apartment!
Well, then I get to give him the cell phone.
Okay. All right. (Hands her the phone.) Good luck explaining all the calls to China.
Hi!
(To Rachel) Wow! How long were we arguing for?
(laughs) Youre not the man who left the cell phone.
No thats my assistant.
Is-is he coming? (Looks hopefully out the door.)
Umm, no.
Could you-could you umm, give us one second?
Sure!
Well be right back sir.
Sure.
Wh-what do we do?
I dont know!
Can you believe this? (Rachel exhales in amazement.) We were waiting for a hot guy and then an even hotter one shows up!
I know! (Realizes what Phoebe said.) What?!
Hmm, they just dont make em like that anymore!
(turning and looking at Tom again) No-no they do but, you just have to wait.
Rachel, listenI mean, if you let me have him then I will really owe you one.
(fake disappointment) All right. All right Phoebe I will let you have him, but you owe me; you owe me big!
Yeah! Youre such a great friend!
Ohh
So, which one of you lovely ladies am I going to take to dinner huh?
Oh thatd be me. Sir. (Hands him the cell phone.) After you.
Okay. Okay. (Exits and Phoebe checks him out.)
(whispering) Nice!
Well, you certainly own that room.
Actually I rent the whole place and, I just got what you meant. Thank you.
Hi.
Hey!
Oh my God! Oh my God!! Ohh, Jessica Lockhart!! In my apartment!! I am such a huge fan! I am such a huge fan!
Well, its nice to know that you
(screaming) MONICA!!!! MONICA!!!! (Runs to Monicas.)
That uh, that is my roommate Rachel.
Oh that explains all the womens underwear.
(shrugs) Sure. Yep.
(entering with Rachel) Oh my God! Its true!! Oh my God you are so amazing! Oh my God, can I just ask you to do me oh, just one favor?
Certainly.
Would you slap me? Would you slap me right here in the face?! (Points to her cheek.)
Id love to, but my lawyer said I cant do that anymore.
God. You seem really, really nice.
Okay, bye-bye.
I mean n-not-not fake at all like most famous people.
All right, here we go. (He grabs them and starts to pull them out of the apartment.)
Okay.
(breaks away) Oh wait, just one more thing! One more minute! (To Cecilia) Umm, youre a stupid bitch.
I really cant slap you. (Monica walks away angrily)
You are so beautiful.
Nice to meet you! My God youre great!
Thanks for stopping by. See ya! (Throws them out and closes the door.) (To Cecilia) I-I am so sorry. I
Oh no-no-no-no, being adored. Im used to it, dont worry about it.
(notices something in the mail that Rachel brought in) Oh my God!
What?
They sent me todays script! They never send the script!
They dont?
Well no, Im just in a coma. This must mean I have lines! (Realizes what that means.) Oh
How does it happen?
(flipping to the last page) Ew, you get thrown from a horse into an electric fence.
Ah what?! Jessica hates horses!
Yeah well, Im guessing after this shes not going to be crazy about electricity either.
now remember you have to imagine me in a kilt.
(giggles) (To Ross) I can imagine you in a short plaid skirt and knee socks.
(To Rachel) Do you wanna start telling secrets?
No!
(stands up) Now umm, remember Im still learning.
One, two, three, four!
You know the song! Sing along!
So?
Loosening the saddle on mothers horse was brilliant Fredrick. And the electric fence, inspired.
Thank you sweetheart. (They clink glasses.)
I cant believe shes really gone. Look around you, all of this is ours. (They move into kiss but; theyre stopped by Joey entering with a huge bandage wrapped around his head.)
(as Jessica) I dont think so.
Who are you?!
Whats the matter Dina? Dont you recognize your own (Does a hair flip) mother?!
(running out to Joey) That was so wonderful! (Hugs him) Ohh, I think that youre a better Jessica than I ever was!
Oh noo
Well of course not, but you were very good.
Thanks!
And guess what? Good news! I got another job!
Great! Hey! All right! Well-well what is it?!
A film in Guadalajara!
The airport?
No thats La Guardia. (Joey nods in recognition.) This is Mexico.
Ohh. Wow! Well how-how, how will you be gone?
Eight months.
Thats a really long time.
Yeah, but you can come and visit me. I bet that you could uh, own a few places down there.
Well I tell ya, I should probably buy a place in the city first. (Realizes.) And I just got what you meant againThat isI tell ya, that is a tricky one!
That is a tricky one. Well, Joey I really wanna thank you. Youve, well you made a very difficult time for me a little less painful.
Good luck.
You too.
You know the song! Sing along!
Eeee!!! Eee!! Eee!!
Eee!! (This causes more laughter.)
Do it again!
Zachary Rosenblatt Story by: Brian Buckner & Sebastian Jones Directed by: David Schwimmer Transcribed by: Eric Aasen
Hi.

Hi.

Im not allowed to have soda.
Okay. Well thats pretty much all that we haveOh! Oh! Have you ever had a virgin margarita? (Holds up a bottle of margarita mix.)

Easy for you to say; youll be wearing a veil.

You mean the guy who kept staring at your chest?
Can you blame him?
Sorry, I just dont like the idea of when I say, "I do," hes thinking, "Yeah, Id do her too!"
Well then we still have a problem.
Yeah!
(returning with Joey) With what?
Well, were trying to find someone to perform our wedding and theyre all either boring or annoying or yknow, cant stop staring at the ladies. (Points to her chest.)
Oo! You should have one of us do it!
Phoebe, were getting married, married; not sixth grade married.
No! No! Its-its uh a real thing! Anyone can get ordained on the Internet and perform like weddings and stuff!
Are you serious?
Yes! A friend of mine did it and its totally legal!
I call it!!
What?! No! It was my idea!
Guys thank you very much but neither of you is marrying us.
Does calling it not mean anything anymore?!
We are going to have a legitimate member of the clergy! And when I say legitimate I mean, gay and in control of his saliva!
Ben yknow when uh, when you were a baby, you and I used to hang out all the time. Cause I was, I was your daddys girlfriend.
But youre not anymore!
No, Im not.
Cause you guys were on a break.
Hey! We were not on aOkay. Thats fine! Fine. Yknow what Ben? One day when you are a lot older I am going to tell you that entire story over a pitcher of real margaritas, okay?
Whens my daddy coming back?
(checks her watch) Fifty-two minutes. (Pause) So no-no brothers and sisters, huh? That must be nice. You dont have to share stuff.
Sharing is good.
Oh, youre one of those. But yknow what? I have two sisters of my own and we just-just tortured each other.
Really? Like how?
Well yknow, we would umm, repeat everything the other said, or uh, wed jump out of closets to scare each other, or switch the sugar for the salt so theyd put salt on their cereal.
(laughs) Thats a good one.
Yeah? You like that one?
Yeah, youre funny.

Im funny? Oh thank God! Well hey, Ive got a ton of these! Umm, oh hearDo you want a good one? Heres a good one. Umm, you uh, you take a quarter, take a quarter and, and you blacken the edge. Right? (Does so.) And then you say to person, I bet you cant roll this quarter from your forehead to your chin without it leaving your face. And then when they do it, theyre left with a big black pencil line right down the center of their face.
Can I do it to you?
Yeah, I-I-I-Im funny Ben, but Im not stupid. Okay?
So, did you uh, find anyone to marry you guys yet?
No, but Horny for Monica Minister called, wanting to know if we were still together.
Were never gonna find anybody.
Well then let me do it!
Joe
No-no-no! Look, Ive been thinking about it. Im an actor right? So I wont get nervous talking in front of people.
Joey look its really sweet
No-no-no-no look no! I wont spit, and I wont stare at Monicas breasts! Yknow? Everyone knows Im an ass man!
That is true.

Yeah and the most important thing is that it wont be some like, stranger up there who barely knows you. Itll be me! And I swear Ill do a really good job. Plus, yknow I love you guys and-and it would really mean a lot to me.
(To Monica) Yknow, we havent found anybody else.
It might be kinda cool.
So I can do it?
Yeah you can do it.
All right!!! Okay!! All right! Okay-okay, I gotta get started on my speech! Oh, wait a minute, Internet ministers can still have sex right?
Yeah.
Okay.

Oh, I have a headache. A horrible headache!

Oh my God, youve got to stop chattering!
Here, take a couple of these. (She gets up to grab a couple of pills.)
What is it?

Oh no, I dont believe in Western medicine. No, if you just apply pressure to these points right here. (Shes pinching the bit of skin between her right thumb and forefinger with her left hand.) Then your hand starts to hurt and you still have a headache, so thanks. (Takes the pills.)

Okay, while were waiting for these pills to kick in, Im gonna sit you down on the couch. Come on. (Phoebe gets up and goes with her.) Get some nice soft pillows under your head, Im gonna turn the TV on and you can watch whatever you want. And ImSit down(She sits down on the couch)gonna make you some tea. And then, Im gonna rub your feet.
Oh.
Oh! My head! Oh! (Hes sitting on the chair, lies back, and puts his feet up for Monica to rub.) Oh!
Coming.
I have a bone to pick with you.
Uh-oh.
Yes! Ben learned a little trick.

Thats right! Thats right! Saran Wrap on the toilet seat so the pee goes everywhere!
Oh that.
Yeah that! You know I hate practical jokes! Theyre mean and theyre stupid and-and I dont want my son learning them!
Oh, come on! Saran Wrap on the toilet seat, you dont think thats just a little funny?!
I was barefoot. Now tell me, the toilet thing is the only thing you taught him right?
(looking at his mark) Yes.
Its amazing! My headache is completely gone! What are those pills called?
Hexadrin. (She gets the box out of her purse.)
Oh, I love you Hexadrin! (She kisses the box.) Oh look! It comes with a story! (She pulls out the instructions and side affects paper.)
No Phoebe, those are like the side affects and stuff.
Say what?

Oh my God! (Starts reading them.) Dizziness, nervousness, drowsiness, facial swelling, nausea, headacheHeadache. Vomiting, stomach bleeding, liver damage! Now okay, I dont recall any of this coming up when you gave me these little death capsules! Oh Im sorry, extra strength death capsules!
Phoebe, relax none of that stuff ever happens! They just put it on there for legal reasons!

In case it happens.

Hey!

Our minister
I have liver damage. Ow! Oh! (She grabs the left side of her torso.)

Okay.

(Phoebe nods her approval.) "We too can share and love and have and receive."
(To Monica) Should we call the spitter?

Oh, interesting you should call me that! Now that I may never have one! (Holds up the warning label.)

(reading) "When I think of the love that these two givers and receivers share, I can not help but envy the lifetime ahead of having and loving and giving and" And then I cant think of a good word for right here. (He points to the stop on the paper where he left off.)

Joey! Joey! Joey! J-J-Joey-Joey-J-Joey! (Monica hides under the covers as Joey enters. Remember?)

And it is a love that is based on having and giving and receiv(Shuts up on Monicas glare.)

Okay, its just weird! Okay? I dont want to be standing their saying my vows and then having the mental image of you and Monica! I-I-I needI dont know what I need. I need a walk.
Wait Chandler come on, letsits not a big deal!
It is to me. You wanted to sleep with Batman, and instead you had to settle for Robin. (Walks out and slams the door.)

That you and daddy were not on a break.

Rachel! What are you doing here?
Im just visiting my good friend Carol.
Your good friend?

Whats her last name?
CarolLesbian?
Nice. And by the way that uh, that line down my face?

(entering from the kitchen) Hey Ross!
Hi.

Practical jokes.

Fine. Fine, but Ill have you know that once I taught him that stuff he called me Fun Aunt Rachel. And I loved being Fun Aunt Rachel but Ill go back to being Boring and Uncomfortable Aunt Rachel if thats what you want!
No thats not what I want. Uh, Im glad you guys were bonding but I

(yelling from off camera) Crap!!
I gotta go! (Runs out.)
Hey.
Hey. Do you want this scone? (Holds up his plate) It came for me but it would probably rather sleep with you!

Look Joe, I know you wanted to do the wedding

How can I not be upset? Okay? I finally fall in love with this fantastic woman and it turns out that she wanted you first!

Yeah for like a half an hour one night! Chandler, she wants you for the rest of her life! Youre so lucky! Look what I missed out on by not being there! Although you know what? It could never have worked like you guys did, cause you guys are perfect for each other. Yknow, we look at you and-and we see you together and it justit-it fits. Yknow? And you just know its gonna last forever.
Thats what you should say.
What?
When youre marrying us; thats what you should say.
Really? I can do it?
Id love it if you would do it.
Hey! (They hug.)
